title: This Cursed Earth
description:
This Cursed Earth is a site about places you can visit that are unique, rare, dark and mysterious. It is a real website that is online and under constant development.

The site is built with Tailwind CSS and JavaScript, and uses Firebase as its database.

title: Community Science Museum
description:
The Community Science Museum was our first semester project at Noroff. We were given clear guidelines on how to complete the assignment. For example, we were not allowed to use JavaScript—only HTML and CSS. The design needed to be child-friendly but not overly childish. The task described a museum for older children, so I aimed for a design that could be fun for kids. I created Professor Kaos, a character I drew myself, and incorporated into various parts of the site.

I also designed the logo, which features a test tube cleverly used as both the 'I' and 'U' in the name.

title: Rainy Days

image.text: About Us page of Rainy Days

description:
Rainy Days was our first assignment focused on learning JavaScript. The main task was to create a functioning shopping system where users could add products to a shopping cart, adjust the cart, and complete a checkout process. We were given the option to continue working on our very first project or choose one of the other two options and start from scratch. I chose to start fresh, as I felt it offered more learning opportunities by building it from the ground up.

For this assignment, everything from the logo to the products was pre-designed. However, I was free to customize the logo to my liking and select a color scheme to build the overall design around.

title: Secret Oslo
description: Secret Oslo is a site I created to experiment further with what I learned during the JavaScript module at Noroff. I wanted to deepen my understanding of APIs, and it all started with retrieving information from a couple of free API services to display the weather and time in Oslo. Next, I wanted to experiment more with map functions, GPS, and how to integrate them into a site like this. Using text I had previously written about Oslo, the project took off. Although this was initially a site I created to improve my skills in APIs and JavaScript, I was so pleased with the result that I purchased a domain for it, and the site is now live online.

title: NorWave
description:
NorWave was mine final exam project for the first year at Noroff, where we were required to apply everything we had learned throughout the year. This meant working exclusively with HTML, CSS, JS, and APIs. We had the option to use a business concept provided by the school or come up with our own idea. I chose to create my own concept.

My idea was inspired by an initiative from the Norwegian government in the 1990s, when a wave of great Norwegian films was promoted under the name NorWave. I imagined how a modern website for that purpose would look today. I started by designing a logo that referenced both film and waves. Once the logo was complete, I based the rest of the website's design around it.

In addition to a feature for creating news posts, the site also includes a film database showcasing Norwegian films.

title: Metal Travels
description:
Metal Travels focuses on travel destinations related to hard rock and heavy metal. Here you can navigate your way through rock bars and metal pubs, restaurants, venues, statues and graves – all connected to metal culture.

Metal Travels is a real website that I built with WordPress as the backbone. In addition to customising a theme for the site’s design, I also created my own plugin so that users can register the places they’ve visited, as well as a separate plugin for navigation on the site.

title: Bugøynes Festival
description:
This is the website for Bugøynes Festival, a small festival in the village of Bugøynes in the far north of Norway. Despite being held in a small village, the festival features relatively major artists on the Norwegian music scene.

The website is built using HTML, CSS and JavaScript. In addition, the volunteer application form uses Firebase as its database.

title: Hell on Earth

image.text: Home page of Hell on Earth

description:
Hell on Earth is a site with editorial content about music, film, travel and much more. The site is run by me and is a fairly informal place where I post reviews, interviews and news whenever I feel like it.

The site is built using WordPress, with a customised design based on a pre-made theme solution.

title: My Liquor Shelf
description:
My Liquor Shelf is a site I created to keep track of my home bar and the cocktail recipes I like. Since there wasn’t already a site that did exactly what I wanted, I decided to make one myself.

The site uses Firebase as its database and is built with Tailwind CSS and JavaScript.

title: Howling
description: Howling is a social media client built with Tailwind CSS and JavaScript modules. The portfolio update focuses on making the authentication flow feel more professional, reducing “dev-style” alerts, and handling protected pages in a clearer, user-friendly way.

title: Chopping Mall
description: Chopping Mall is a Next.js webshop where the focus is component structure, routing, state management, and a smooth user flow from product listing to product detail and checkout success.

title: Rusty Relics
description: Rusty Relics is an auction marketplace application built with the Noroff Auction API. For the portfolio update, I focused on polishing UX details and tightening the codebase around pagination, user feedback messages, and listing media presentation.

title: Square Eyes

image.text: About Us page of Square Eyes

description:
Square Eyes was our first assignment at Noroff. We were given three options to build a website from, and I chose the streaming site Square Eyes. We were provided with the logo and clear guidelines on how the site should be designed. As a result, I mainly adapted the logo in terms of colours. I drew inspiration from well-known streaming platforms like Netflix, Amazon Prime, HBO, etc.

Square Eyes is primarily built using only HTML and CSS, as these were the main focus of the assignment. I used just a bit of JavaScript to make the carousel function properly. Despite being just a mock-up site focused on design, it works well and offers good user functionality.
